## Choropleth Mapping Introduction

- A choropleth map is a type of thematic map in which areas are <u>shaded or patterned</u> according to a data variable. The variable is categorized into intervals, with each interval represented by a colour, and the map filled accordingly. Colour progression is used to represent the differences, often blending from dark to light or one colour to another. The choropleth map provides an easy way to show how a measurement varies across a geographic area, or the level of variability within a region.

::: footer
Source:[UNHCR Datviz](https://dataviz.unhcr.org/chart-types/geospatial/#:~:text=A%20choropleth%20map%20is%20a,of%20variability%20within%20a%20region.)
:::

## Choropleth Mapping Introduction

### Geometry of Thematic Mapping - 'Spine' vs 'Off-Spine'

- 'Spine' geographies nest perfectly within each other, from blocks up to the nation.
- 'Off-Spine' geographies often have higher MOE.

![](index_files/img/spine.png){.absolute top="400" left="700" width="400"}

::: footer
Source:[CTData Collaborative](https://www.ctdata.org/blog/understanding-census-geography)

## Choropleth Mapping Methods - Classification

- **Linear** (Equal interval or rather equal-sized numerical bins). Suitable for 'normal' distributions.
- **Quantile** (bins of equal number - 4, 5 or 10). Suitable for 'skewed' distributions.

## Choropleth Mapping Methods - Classification

- **Natural Breaks** (bins are relatively narrow; differences between bins are prioritized). Suitable for many distributions.
- **Standard Deviation**(bins are organized above, then below, a mid-point, typically mean). Suitable for 'normal' distributions.
